case_name: Ramnagina Rai v. Bishundeo Rai, Sheo Deo Prasad Rai, Mohan Rai, Jangli Rai and the appellant

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 33 of 1969 was filed in the Supreme Court by special leave against the judgment and order dated 12th November 1968 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 58 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 33 of 1969. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 12th November, 1968 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 58 of 1966.

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside the acquittal of the appellant by the Additional Sessions Judge of Chapra and convicted him under section 82(d) of the Indian Registration Act and sentenced him to six months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the judgment passed in Criminal Appeal No. 58/1966 whereby the High Court of Patna set aside the acquittal of the appellant by the Additional Sessions Judge of Chapra and convicted him under section 82 d  of the Indian Registration Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and sentenced him to six months rigorous imprisonment,

facts.text: Ramnagina Rai filed a complaint before the Sub-Divisional Officer, Sadar, Chapra, against Bishundeo Rai, Sheo Deo Prasad Rai, Mohan Rai, Jangli Rai and the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: One Ramnagina Rai filed a companyplaint before the Sub-Divi- sional Officer, Sadar, Chapra, against Bishundeo Rai. Sheo Deo Prasad Rai, Mohan Rai, Jangli Rai and the appellant stating that they entered into a companyspiracy

facts.text: The accused entered into a conspiracy and forged a Zerpeshgi deed on 25-1-1964 purporting to be executed by Bishundeo Rai and Nageshwar Rai in favour of Jangli Rai.

anchor.surface_text: stating that they entered into a companyspiracy and forged a Zerpeshgi deed on 25-1-1964 purporting to be executed by Bishundeo Rai and Nageshwar Rai in favour of Jangli Rai in which Sheo Deo Prasad Rai falsely personated Nageshwar Rai.

facts.text: Sheo Deo Prasad Rai falsely personated Nageshwar Rai.

anchor.surface_text: in which Sheo Deo Prasad Rai falsely personated Nageshwar Rai. The Sessions Court, to which the case was companymitted, after trial, came to the companyclusion that Sheo Deo Prasad Rai, posing as Nageshwar, son of Bujhawan.

facts.text: The case was committed to the Sessions Court after trial.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Court, to which the case was companymitted, after trial, came to the companyclusion that Sheo Deo Prasad Rai, posing as Nageshwar, son of Bujhawan. executed the Zerpeshgi deed

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge of Chapra concluded that Sheo Deo Prasad Rai posed as Nageshwar son of Bujhawan and executed the Zerpeshgi deed.

anchor.surface_text: came to the companyclusion that Sheo Deo Prasad Rai, posing as Nageshwar, son of Bujhawan. executed the Zerpeshgi deed and that Sheo Deo Prasad Rai falsely personated as Nageshwar before the Sub- Registrar,

facts.text: No such person as Nageshwar existed.

anchor.surface_text: that Sheo Deo Prasad Rai falsely personated as Nageshwar before the Sub- Registrar, that numbersuch person as Nageshwar existed and that Bishundeo Rai, the father of Sheo Deo Prasad Rai and company executant of the document was a party to the forgery.

facts.text: Bishundeo Rai was a party to the forgery.

anchor.surface_text: numbersuch person as Nageshwar existed and that Bishundeo Rai, the father of Sheo Deo Prasad Rai and company executant of the document was a party to the forgery. The Court, therefore, companyvicted Bishundeo Rai and Sheo Deo Prasad Rai

facts.text: Sessions Court convicted Bishundeo Rai and Sheo Deo Prasad Rai under sections 467 and 120B of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Court, therefore, companyvicted Bishundeo Rai and Sheo Deo Prasad Rai of offences under section 467 and section 120 B of the Indian Penal Code. Bishundeo and Sheo Deo Prasad were also companyvicted under section 82 d  and 82 c  respectively of the Act.

facts.text: Bishundeo Rai convicted under section 82(d) and Sheo Deo Prasad Rai under section 82(c) of the Act by Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: Bishundeo and Sheo Deo Prasad were also companyvicted under section 82 d  and 82 c  respectively of the Act. The remaining three accused were given the benefit of doubt , and acquitted.

facts.text: Remaining three accused including appellant acquitted by Sessions Court given benefit of doubt.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining three accused were given the benefit of doubt , and acquitted. Two appeals were filed from this judgment to the High Court, namely, Criminal Appeal No. 205/1966 and Criminal Appeal No. 58/ 1966.

facts.text: Two appeals filed to Patna High Court: Criminal Appeal No. 205/1966 and Criminal Appeal No. 58/1966.

anchor.surface_text: Two appeals were filed from this judgment to the High Court, namely, Criminal Appeal No. 205/1966 and Criminal Appeal No. 58/ 1966. We are only companycerned with the appeal filed by the companyplainant against the acquittal of the appellant, namely, Criminal Appeal No. 58/1966.

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 58/1966 filed by complainant against acquittal of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We are only companycerned with the appeal filed by the companyplainant against the acquittal of the appellant, namely, Criminal Appeal No. 58/1966. In that appeal, the High Court came to the companyclusion that the, Sessions Judge was wrong in acquitting the appellant

facts.text: Patna High Court found clear evidence that appellant identified Sheo Deo Prasad Rai as Nageshwar son of Bujhawan before the Sub-Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: In that appeal, the High Court came to the companyclusion that the, Sessions Judge was wrong in acquitting the appellant as there was clear evidence that it was be who identified Sheo Deo Prasad Rai as Nageshwar, son of Bujhawan, before the Sub-Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court, the only point argued on behalf of the appellant was that the companyplaint was incompetent as it was filed by a person without obtaining the necessary permission under section 83 of the Act and, therefore, the companyviction was bad and must be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Section 82 deals with four classes of offences classified under  a ,  b ,  c  and  d  of the section. issues.text: Whether the complaint was incompetent as it was filed by a person without obtaining the necessary permission under section 83 of the Indian Registration Act and therefore the conviction was bad and must be set aside

anchor.surface_text: In this Court, the only point argued on behalf of the appellant was that the complaint was incompetent as it was filed by a person without obtaining the necessary permission under section 83 of the Act and, therefore, the conviction was bad and must be set aside. Section 83 of the Act

issues.text: Whether section 83 of the Indian Registration Act is prohibitory in character so as to preclude private prosecutions for offences under the Act or is merely permissive and enabling

anchor.surface_text: The section is not prohibitory in that it does not preclude a private person from commencing a prosecution. Even in a case where the commission of an offence comes to the knowledge of the Registering Officer in his official capacity, the section does not prohibit a private person from commencing a prosecution as the section is clearly permissive in its language and intent. In other words, the section is an enabling one.

arguments.claim: The complaint was incompetent as it was filed by a person without obtaining the necessary permission under section 83 of the Act and therefore the conviction was bad and must be set aside

anchor.surface_text: In this Court, the only point argued on behalf of the appellant was that the complaint was incompetent as it was filed by a person without obtaining the necessary permission under section 83 of the Act and, therefore, the conviction was bad and must be set aside.

arguments.claim: Section 83 deals only with offences coming to knowledge of registering officer officially and has no application otherwise; it is not prohibitory

anchor.surface_text: On a reading of the section, it would be clear that it deals only with prosecution for an offence under the Act coming to the knowledge of the Registering Officer in his official capacity. It, in effect, provides that where an offence comes to the knowledge of the Registering Officer in his official capacity, a prosecution may be commenced by or with the permission of any of the officers mentioned in the section.

arguments.claim: Section 83 is not prohibitory and does not preclude private prosecution even when offence known to registering officer officially; it is permissive and enabling

anchor.surface_text: The section is not prohibitory in that it does not preclude a private person from commencing a prosecution. Even in a case where the commission of an offence comes to the knowledge of the Registering Officer in his official capacity, the section does not prohibit a private person from commencing a prosecution as the section is clearly permissive in its language and intent.

arguments.claim: Section 83 enables officers to commence prosecution without personal risk

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the section is an enabling one. It enables the persons mentioned therein to commence a prosecution in cases where the commission of the offence under the Act comes to the knowledge of the Registering Officer in his official capacity. The Section enables the officers named to use their official position for the purpose of prosecution without personal risk.

arguments.claim: Precedents hold section 83 not prohibitory: Gopinath v. Kuldip Singh (Calcutta Full Bench), Re Piranu Nadathi (Madras), Emperor v. Yesa Nath Bidwagh (Bombay), Ganga Dibya v. Emperor (Patna), Habib Shah v. Mehda Shah (J&K)

anchor.surface_text: In Gopinath v. Kuldip Singh and others , the question whether the section prohibits a private person from commencing a prosecution without the permission as provided in the section, came up for consideration and a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court answered the question by saying that the section is not prohibitory in character and that it does not preclude a private person from commencing a prosecution for an offence under the Act without the permission as envisaged in the section.

arguments.claim: Rangoon High Court in Nge Pan Gaing v. King Emperor and Allahabad Full Bench in Emperor v. Mohd. Mehdi wrongly read section 83 as mandatory

anchor.surface_text: In Nge Pan Gaing and other v. King Emperor 6 , the Rangoon High Court held that the word may in section 83 of the Act should be read as equivalent to must beand that a prosecution for an offence under the Act coming to the knowledge of a Registering Officer in his official capacity cannot be commenced by a private person without the permission mentioned in the section.

arguments.court_reasoning: Inadmissible reading as section provides only for specific cases and is permissive

arguments.claim: Interpreting section 83 as mandatory would lead to policy consequence of total bar to prosecution if authorities collude or fail to act, especially for offences under sections 81 and 82

anchor.surface_text: If the authorities mentioned in section 83 of the Act were to collude with the person guilty of an. offence under section 82 of the Act, or if they fail to launch a prosecution against the registering officer for an offence under section 81 of the Act, there, would be a total bar to prosecution by a private person in case we accept the reasoning of the Rangoon and Allahabad High Courts.

arguments.claim: No reason to prohibit private prosecution when private person is seriously injured by forgery and registration, or to give immunity to guilty registering officer under section 81

anchor.surface_text: Seeing that a private person will be more seriously injured by the action of an offender who not only forges a document but endeavors to give it a higher efficacy by registering it, we can perceive no reason why the private person should be denied the liberty to prosecute the offender. We also see no reason why a registering officer guilty of an offence under section 81 of the Act should get immunity from prosecution by a private individual injured thereby.

arguments.claim: Section 83 is prohibitory in character as per K. M. Kanavi v. State of Mysore

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant referred to the decision of this Court in K. M. Kanavi v. State of Mysore 1  and contended that section 83 of the Act is prohibitory in character.

arguments.court_reasoning: No merit as language of provision in Kanavi was totally different

anchor.surface_text: We think that, on the point under consideration. the decisions in Gopinath v. Kuldip Singh and others  2   , Re Piranu Nodathi and others 3 , and Emperor v. Yesa Nana Didwagh and others 4  lay down the correct law.

It, in effect, provides that where an offence comes to the knowledge of the Registering Officer in his official capacity,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of the section limits its application to offences known officially to registering officer

holdings.text: The section is not prohibitory in that it does not preclude a private person from commencing a prosecution even where commission of offence comes to knowledge of Registering Officer officially; it is permissive and enabling

anchor.surface_text: The section is not prohibitory in that it does not preclude a private person from commencing a prosecution. Even in a case where the commission of an offence comes to the knowledge of the Registering Officer in his official capacity, the section does not prohibit a private person from commencing a prosecution as the section is clearly permissive in its language and intent. In other words, the section is an enabling one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permissive language ('may'); enables officers without personal risk; supported by precedents; policy avoids bar if collusion; contrasts with prohibitory statutes

holdings.text: Decisions in Gopinath v. Kuldip Singh, Re Piranu Nadathi, Emperor v. Yesa Nath Bidwagh lay down the correct law on section 83

anchor.surface_text: We think that, on the point under consideration. the decisions in Gopinath v. Kuldip Singh and others  2   , Re Piranu Nodathi and others 3 , and Emperor v. Yesa Nana Didwagh and others 4  lay down the correct law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alignment with textual, purposive interpretation and policy considerations

holdings.text: Contention that section 83 is prohibitory based on K. M. Kanavi v. State of Mysore has no merit as language of provision there considered was totally different

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant referred to the decision of this Court in K. M. Kanavi v. State of Mysore 1  and contended that section 83 of the Act is prohibitory in character. There is no merit in this contention as the language of the provision there considered was totally different.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction based on textual differences from analogous case

anchor.surface_text: The section is not prohibitory in that it does not preclude a private person from commencing a prosecution. Even in a case where the commission of an offence comes to the knowledge of the Registering Officer in his official capacity, the section does not prohibit a private person from commencing a prosecution as the section is clearly permissive in its language and intent. In other words, the section is an enabling one.
